pullRequest.body: This PR proves Lucas' theorem, which states that $\binom{n}{k} \equiv \prod_i \binom{\lfloor n / p^i \rfloor \pmod{p}}{\lfloor k / p^i \rfloor \pmod{p}} \equiv \prod_i \binom{n_i}{k_i} \pmod{p}$, where $n_i$ and $k_i$ are the $i$-th base-$p$ digits of $n$ and $k$ respectively. This is proven by looking at Freshman's dream closely + induction

end Choose'

If you really care about the `if ... then ... else ...` changes, can you make them a separate PR? In fact, since I'm asking you to drop `prod_ite_eq_iff`, you can simply remove from this PR all the changes outside of `Data.Nat.Choose.Lucas` and `Algebra.CharP.Basic`
You still have this lemma. Accident?
maintainer merge

Hmm I'm not sure about this one, especially not as a simp lemma. I could just about believe that it's awkward to rewrite to get this by prod_ite_eq then h, but I worry that simp will try to prove `h` in cases where it's a big time sink
Sorry for the late reply. Should I remove the attr then?
Write out if...then...else
and below
Couldn't this be an independent lemma?
I don't know the proof here, but the question above prompts asking if you can decompose this proof into further pieces!

This lemma is saying that $(X + 1)^n \equiv (X + 1)^{n \pmod{p}}(X^p + 1)^{\lfloor n / p \rfloor} \pmod{p}$ which follows because $(X + 1)^n \equiv (X + 1)^{n \pmod{p} + \lfloor n / p \rfloor \cdot p} \pmod{p}$ then use Freshman's dream. I will isolate it out into `Mathlib/Algebra/CharP/Basic.lean` then :D
Missing some mods in the statement here.
Should the statement mention the bounds hypotheses?

This is saying that $\binom{n}{k} \equiv \prod_i \binom{\lfloor n / p^i \rfloor}{\lfloor k / p^i \rfloor} \pmod{p}$ over all $i$ (but the floor eventually vanishes). Do you think the bounds requirement needs to be mentioned?
Also I don't see where the "missing mods" are. It's saying that "..." is congruent to "product of "..." over i" modulo p.
The right hand side contains `choose (n / p ^ i % p) (k / p ^ i % p)`: both arguments have a `% p` which isn't reflected in your informal statement.
Is it a good `simp` lemma? Also, you rewrite many `ite`s as `if .. then .. else ..` but use `ite` here.

Yes, the `ite -> if ... then ... else ...` is my mistake. About the `simp` attribute, I just copied the definition above for `prod_ite_eq` without much thought. But now that I think about it, since the lemma requires a iff hypothesis `(h : ∀ x ∈ f.support, p x ↔ a = x)`, it won't ever be triggered by `simp` I think, or at least very very rarely. So I will remove the [simp].

```suggestion
    (filter p s).card = ∑ a ∈ s, if p a then 1 else 0 := by simp [sum_ite]
```

```suggestion
    (a : α) : ∏ i, (if p i then a else 1) = if ∃ i, p i then a else 1 := by
```

Please don't indent docstrings by default
```suggestion
choose (n / p) (k / p)` modulo `p`. -/
```
Why does this one not get a docstring?
I don't think we want that lemma? It's just a `prod_congr` away from an existing one
IIRC I copied it from `Algebra/BigOperators/Finsupp.lean`. I will remove it
Seems like you also added the `Algebra.BigOperators.Finsupp` one 🤔
lmfao sorry

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion `choose (⌊n / p ^ i⌋ % p) (⌊k / p ^ i⌋ % p)` over i < a, multiplied by ```

```suggestion
theorem lucas_theorem' (a : ℕ) :
    choose n k ≡
      choose (n / p ^ a) (k / p ^ a) * ∏ i in range a, choose (n / p ^ i % p) (k / p ^ i % p) [ZMOD p] := by
```
so that it stays somewhat readable
That makes the third line exceed 100 characters. I tried my best in the latest commit.

What about
```suggestion
theorem lucas_theorem' (a : ℕ) :
    choose n k ≡ choose (n / p ^ a) (k / p ^ a) *
      ∏ i in range a, choose (n / p ^ i % p) (k / p ^ i % p) [ZMOD p] := by
```
so that it stays somewhat readable

```suggestion
theorem choose_modEq_choose_mod_mul_choose_div : choose n k ≡ choose (n % p) (k % p) * choose (n / p) (k / p) [ZMOD p] := by
```
I prefer the semantic names over names obsessed with symbol-reading
I find this quite unreadable personally, especially for a (decently) well-known theorem "in this area". I will make these changes but add an alias below.

```suggestion
theorem choose_modEq_prod_range_choose {a : ℕ} (ha₁ : n < p ^ a) (ha₂ : k < p ^ a) :
```

```suggestion
theorem choose_modEq_choose_mul_prod_range_choose (a : ℕ) :
```

```suggestion
* `choose_modEq_prod_range_choose`: the binomial coefficient `n choose k` is congruent to the
```
@Parcly-Taxel, please don't merge in your own suggestions on someone else's PR when they are potentially contentious
I have a hard time thinking this unambiguously refers to Lucas theorem
It's (somewhat trivially) equivalent to the product version, and potentially useful at times, but I can remove the theorem label for it.
Oh I meant the lemma name, not the statement

```suggestion
This file contains a proof of [Lucas's theorem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lucas's_theorem) about
```

```suggestion
  simp_rw [Nat.div_eq_of_lt ha₁, Nat.div_eq_of_lt ha₂, choose, cast_one, one_mul, cast_prod,
    Int.ModEq.refl]
```
This looks like `n` and `p` should be explicit. If you're willing to fix it, can you open a separate PR to fix it in the entire file (to avoid scope creep here)
Oops I missed this, I will do it yes
@YaelDillies I think `p` doesn't have to be explicit since `x` and `y` would infer `R` which should uniquely infer `p` - at least mathematically the second part is true?

Mathematically, yes. In practice, not really 😢 

Try it for yourself by rewriting using your lemmas with `R` instantiated to specific char `p` rings, like `ZMod p` or `Fin p`.
Both sides of this are nats, right? So maybe it'd be nice to have versions using MOD p as well?

I agree with Bhavik here we should have the Nat version.

@grhkm21, would you mind either adding this, or simply saying "sorry, can someone do it in a subsequent PR", and then you can merge?
It should be a `norm_cast` away, I think
How should I name the theorems? I will add some `_nat` and `_int`, but alternatively I can call it `zmod` vs `mod`, but that seems unpopular in Mathlib.
`modEq` and `intModEq`, maybe?
